addressleaf.section:
From
e Queene
e first of Marche 1590.

To our trustie and welbelovid servante Thomas Bodley esquier o
r
Counsello
r
in the
Counsell of State
of the
United Provinces
of the
Lowe Countryes
/

page.lettertext:
fol.102r
Belgia: 1590 Feb
r:
Belgia 1591 Stilo Rom Pre: Martij To M
r
Bodly
Elizabeth R
Trusty and welbeloved wee greete yowe well. Althowgh wee doe
not often write to yowe to showe howe well wee allowe of yo
r
s
rvice
theare: yet bicawse wee have signified often times to o
r
Tr
e
r of
England
o
r
good liking of yowe in o
r
s
rvice theare, and have manie
times when wee directed him to write to yowe, what was o
r
pleasure
to be done by yowe in sundrie o
r
Cawses theare; Commaunded him to
geve yowe knowledge of o
r
good Acceptac
o
n of yo
r
s
rvice, and that
spetiallie for that yowe alwaies pre
s
rved the Estimac
o
n of o
r
princely
authoritie in yo
r
Negotiac
o
n w
th
the States, Therefore wee dowbt
not but havinge knowledge of o
r
favorable acceptaunce of yo
r
s
rvice
yowe will continue the same Corse: And at this time spetiallie also
wee doe allowe of yo
r
discretion in usinge of late o
r
A
uc
tie to staie
certaine o
r
Capteines w
th
their Bandes from repairing from theire plac
of Garrisons to the Sea side, for that yowe understood of the Prohibic
o
n
thereof, by the publicque Commandment of the
States G
n
all
, and
of the Generall murmur and mislikinge of the universall Cuntrye:
And nowe what o
r
Resoluc
o
n hath latelie been, to have the
s
rvice
of the said Bandes w
th
the reasonable good will both of the States
and Cuntrie, wee dowbt not but yowe have understood by letters
written by o
r
Order to yowe, by o
r
Thr
e
r, and shall more perticulerly
understand the same at
S
r
John Norrice
comminge thither by o
r
owne letters, both to the States, and to yo
r
self./
And wheare of late also wee understood that theare was an expec
tation of certaine Ambassado
rs
that weare sent from the
Empero
r
fol.102v
Belgia: 1591: Feb
r:
to offer Conditions of Peace in the
K. of Spaignes
name to thos Cuntries
of
Holland
and
Zeland
, and other the Provinc
United, and that it might be
dowbted that by the perswasion of the said Ambassado
rs
, and by great
conninge of the Ministers of the K. of Spaigne, and otherwise also by the
Papesticall faction on all part
, least the vulger people being also wea-
ried with the warre, might be soe abused and entised w
th
plawsible
wordes, not wiselie looking to the Event and sequell, w
ch
could noe-
wise be but dangerous, and thearebie the States and Gouverno
rs
thowgh
theare understanding might
s
rve them to suspect thos
persons
offers
, might yet
not soe providentlie forsee in the beginninge before the offers showlde be
made to refuse the Coverture of anie Treatie: therefore wee did cawse
a Collection by waie of a Project in writinge to be sent yowe conteininge
A forme of sondrie Argument
howe the States might w
th
honno
r
and
reason, yea with the good allowance of all Princes and States that weare
not partiallie addicted to the K. of Spaigne, or to the
Pope
, refuse to heare
of anie offers of Peace at this time, or to enter into ane Communicac
o
n
or Treatie thereof w
th
anie from the Empero
r
, or from the K. of Spaigne,
or from anie of his Ministers: According to w
ch
Collec
o
n in writinge, being
sent to yowe, wee dowbt not but yowe have as yowe weare directed, pro
ceaded, and proffited thearein, to the avoiding of the great danger that might
otherwise ensewe, if the States showld be negligent to w
th
stand the begin-
ninges of soe dangerous purposes, whearein by all Circumstances of this
time maie be vearie manifestlie discovered, that the intentions of anie
fol.103r
Belgia: 1591: Feb
r:
offers, are grownded onelie uppon dissimulac
o
n, and to the advantage
of the Spaniardes, and anie of thos Lowe Cuntries./ But nowe uppon
later Advertisementz geven us owt of thos Lowe Cuntries, whereof wee
doe nowe hearewith certefie yowe, not knowinge howe trewe the same
are, thowgh the Advertise of duetie signifieth to us, that he feareth
them to be trewe: wee cannot but w
th
more Ernestnes renewe to yowe
as a newe charge, to cawse yowe to be more Carefull hereof, and as
yowe shall finde cawse to thinke them likelie to be trewe, so to endevo
r
yo
r
self w
th
the States Generall, or the Counsell as y
o
maie discover
the trewthe thereof, and accordinglie prosecute the w
th
standinge of the
said reported purposes, or to reverse them utterlie./
The matters to us advertised are thes two./ The first that theare
showld be a purpose to have a meeting at
Utrecht
betwixt the
Duke of
Arscott
, the
Comte Mansfield
, and certaine of the States, and that
Richardott
showld be theare for the K. of Spaigne./.
The second was, that theare was an intention to have a free trafficque
betwixt
Dunkirk
,
Newport
, and other townes of
Flanders
, w
th
Holland
and Zeland./ The first of thes cannot be trewe, but that theare
hath passed aforehand secretlie vearie dangerous practizes, not disco
v
ed
by yowe: neither can the second bringe but danger also to the Common
Cawse, if the same showld prove trewe: and of the latter wee have
more Cawse to thinke it maie be trewe, bicawse wee heare that
both at Dunkirk and Newport, theie are providing of sondrie shippes to
come to thos Seas, and that certaine french Leguer shippes, are to
come w
th
them, and wee doe not understand
that
of
anie shippes of
Flusshinge
to be on the Seas./ Nowe therefore wee will have
yowe speedelie discover whither thes be trewe, or that theare be
anie likehood of the sequell, and if not, yet as yowe maie, yowe
shall discover uppon what Cawse, anie such purpose hath been
reported. And if yowe shall find anie of thes to be intended, y
o
shall then besides the reasons conteined in the former Project, w
ch
yowe weare willed to use as of yo
r
self, plainelie in o
r
name
fol.103v
Belgia: 1591: Feb
r:
as so expreslie directed by us, requier the States Generall, and the
Counsell to Consider, howe neither it can stand w
th
their owne savetie
nor w
th
dewe regard to us, the onelie Prince of Christendome, that
hath openlie protected them, to hir owne danger: nor w
th
theire owne
Bandes and Contract to assent, or to geve eare to anie Treatie of any
Peace or Accord whatsoever w
th
theire Ennemies w
th
owt the knowledge
and avowe of us, neither w
th
anie Prince, or Potentat a stranger
w
th
owt the knowledge of us, or of o
r
Gouverno
r
generall: such are
the expresse wordes of theire Cover
n
nt: as for the daunger that maie
ensue to themselves to accept of anie Condition of Peace or trewce,
whearebie the K. of Spaigne maie for the time use all his forces of thos
Lowe Cuntries against the French K. and consequentlie against us, and
afterwardes to exercise his rooted hatred and his Ambition to Conquer
thos Cuntries, and make them either Spanish and slaves, or vassils to
Spaigne, yowe maie saie to the States, theie cannot be ignorant of the
sequell thereof, having so often published to the world the manifest reasons
of theire like danger, spetiallie when theie shall have abandoned o
r
defence, and shall stand uppon theire owne power farre to weake to
withstand the vearie breathe of such a Conquero
r
, as the K. of Spaigne
mindeth to be. Secondlie howe much it maie towche us in honno
r
to have ventured o
r
State for theire defence, as wee have done, expended
o
r
Treasure, and the lives and substances of a great nomber of o
r
naturall
loving subject
: yowe maie avowe that noe Prince Christened havinge
a Roiall hart can endure such an Injurie or indignitie: And for the
last howe Contrarie it is to theire owne Cove
n
nt, yowe shall write to
them, or deliver to them in writinge, the vearie Article of the Treatye
being the xxj
th
, by w
ch
theie are bownd never to treate w
th
the K. of
Spaigne, w
th
owt o
r
allowance./. And bicawse it maie be that
some of them will saie (as wee have had hath been by some thowgh
untrewlie alledged) at the time o
r
Commissioners treated w
th
the K.
of Spaignes Com
rs
at
Ostend
, that by the next Article beinge the xxij
th
wee weare prohibited to treate w
th
the K. of Spaigne w
th
owt the
fol.104r
Belgia: 1591: Feb
r:
consent of the States: yowe shall require anie of them (if theie shall
be of that minde) to peruse better the wordes of the same Article, [how]
farre the same differeth from theirs: for by the Article on o
r
part
wee are onelie required that it might please us (for so are the
word
) not to treate with the K. of Spaigne in anie thinge concerninge
the state of the Provinces, w
th
owt theire Consent: wheareby first yt
appeareth wee have not Coven
n
ted simplie by anie expresse word
that wee will not treate w
th
the K. of Spaigne w
th
owt theire Consent
for that had been vearie absurd, and farre unreasonable to have exclu-
ded o
r
self generallie from Treatie w
th
the K. of Spaigne, spetially
the same beinge offred to us, beinge a thinge Notorious that wee
maie have manie Cawses for o
r
owne dominions and peple to treate
at anie time w
th
the K. of Spaigne, seperatlie w
th
owt treating for the
state of thos Lowe Cuntries./ And soe wee would have yowe
make it manifest to them, if yowe find anie of them of a Contrarye
minde, that wee are not prohibited by anie wordes that ever passed
from us by speeche or writinge, but that at anie time wee maie treate
to have and keape Peace w
th
the K. of Spaigne for o
r
owne domi-
nions, and yet ob
s
rve the whole Treatie w
th
the States, yea give
them Aide and succo
r
as wee doe, if in makinge of the peace for
o
r
owne Cuntries, the K. of Spaigne in respect of his other Cuntries can
find it convenient for himself, soe to accord w
th
us./ But to
showe howe farre of wee have been to use that libertie in respect of
o
r
Love to the suretie of the States and theire Provinces, It was
manifest to the world howe the K. of Spaigne by his Com
rs
, did offer
to us as good Conditions of Peace, as ever had been betwixt
the Empero
r
his father
, and
the K. o
r
father
, or betwixt o
r
selves,
soe as wee would have left the defence of the States and thos
Provinces: But contrariewise to thos large and favorable offers
wee utterlie refused to assent to anie Accord w
th
the K. for o
r
self
except he would have yelded to the States, a firme peace w
th
all Conditions both of Relligion, and of theire Pollecies & liberties,
is
fol.104v
Belgia 1591 Feb
r:
is largelie as he had been by them hearetofore required. The refusall whe
re
of
on the part of
by us to
the K. of Spaigne, was the onelie cawse that wee refused
the Peace offred by him, by the sequell whereof, it was and is seen into
what danger o
r
Crowne and Realme was browght, and howe ever since
wee and o
r
Realme have been burdened w
th
a most chargeable and dange-
rous warre, whearein wee are yet as the world seeth still encombred-
soe as yt maie appeare wee did not treate to the prejudice of theire
States, but refused peace for o
r
selves, to pre
s
rve theire States entiere./.
Wherefore yowe maie first use thes former reasons as yowe see cawse to
mouve them to forbeare to herken to anie offers w
th
owt o
r
liking: But
to all naturall men of anie wisedome, theare can be noe greater nor more
weightie reason, in the sight of God and man, than this later, when
wee refused peace for theire sakes, whearebie theie are bownd to us, even
for themselves and theire posteritie, w
th
the Bond of all humanitie, besid
the Bond of Revenue, w
ch
theie owe to us, never to assent to anie
offer of peace, or Treces by the K. of Spaigne, w
th
owt o
r
privitie, liking,
and Consent./ Thus wee have deliv
r
ed to y
o
o
r
minde to the
intent to Instruct yowe howe to deale in this great Cawse, if y
o
shall
finde anie disposic
o
n in thos States to herken to anie offer before o
r
assent
be had theareto, accordinge to theire owne Gover
m
t./.
Furdermore of late wee recommended to the States the Consideration of the
state of Ostend, that the same might be strengthened w
th
two Band
more
in respect of the Attempt that might be soddenlie made by the
D. of Parma
nowe whilest he is makinge his preparations for
France
, before he goe
owt of Flanders, and the more wee maie dowbt the state thereof, con-
sideringe the report of the newe preparations of the shippinge owt of
Dunkirk, Newport, and
Graveling
, w
ch
maie be u s ed by Sea to stoppe
the Haven of Ostend, whilest the Ennemies maie assaile the towne by
land, and this matter wee would have yowe most ernestlie present
to the States to be speedelie Considered and provided for, and in noe
wise to be delaied: and that also yowe move them, to sett from shipping
to the Seas to encownter that w
ch
maie be enterprised by them of
fol.105r
Belgia: 1591: Feb
r:
Dunkirk and Newport, and so also wee meane speedelie to Arme
su
m
of o
r
owne shippes to lie uppon thos Coast
, and therefore wee
should greatlie mislike them at this time, if theie would not joine
theire forces w
th
o
rs
, at this apparant time of danger./.
Yowe shall also move them that theire Contributions at Ostend, and
the Cuntrie theareabowt, maie be emploied abowt the Fortifications of
the same Towne, and the defences against the Sea, and thearewith
also that
S
r
Edward Norrece
the Gouvernor theare, whoe de
s
rveth
to be Cherished and mainteined, as theie maie see by his good & valliant
services, maie likewise have his enterteinm
t
enlarged owt of thos Con-
tributions, and so the rest maie be awnsweared to the publicque, as
the States shall thinke meete: Of all thes thing
, aforementioned, wee
require yowe to have Care speedelie, and to advertise us what
yowe shall doe thearein./.
Geven at o
r
Manno
r
of Grenewich the
first daie of Marche: in the xxxiij
th
yeare of o
r
Reigne.
1590.
